channel.title: TFS Top Tip #7 - Determine when TFS Trial Edition will expire
channel.description: UPDATE:  Brian Harry has posted a new utility to help you determine the trial expiration dates on your server.  View Brian's post for more details. Like a lot of early adopters, we installed the Team Foundation Server 180â€“day trial edition...
channel.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by Jeff B.+00:00
item.description:
Here's an on-line date calculator to help calculate the 180 days:
http://www.timeanddate.com/date/dateadd.html
item.dc:creator: Jeff B.

item.title: Comment by Dylan+00:00
item.description: I have Beta 3 Refresh installed. My first changeset date is November 23, 2005. How do I determine when the install will expire? It's obviously not 180 days, as it's nearing 270 now. Is there an expiry? Am I going to be in trouble in 4 days (270 days from install)?
item.dc:creator: Dylan

item.title: Comment by Martin+00:00
item.description:
Dylan. Honestly, I've no idea when (or if) Beta 3 Refresh expires. It is very possible that they didn't put any timebomb code into the early Beta's - but I have no idea.
My honest recommendation would be to migrate to the RTM version ASAP. By sticking on Beta 3R you are exposed to a large number of bugs that the product team know about and have fixed. Also - none of the Team System Extensions currently available will work against Beta 3R.
item.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by smart+00:00
item.description: TFS takes expiration date from registry.
item.dc:creator: smart

item.title: Comment by AbdelMoniem+00:00
item.description: can I install the trial version again on the same machine without reinstalling OS.
item.dc:creator: AbdelMoniem
